docna.cdata!:
Tunisia - Northwest Mountainous and Forestry
            Areas Development Project : environmental assessment

repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Northwest Mountainous and
            Forestry Areas Development Project : environmental assessment

projn:
TN-Northwest Mountainous And Forestry Areas
            Development Project -- P072317
admreg: Middle East and North Africa,Middle East and North Africa
subsc: Agricultural extension and research,Other social services,General agriculture, fishing and forestry sector,Forestry,Crops
trustfund:
TF026699-PHRD-TUNISIA: NORTH-WEST
            MOUNTAINOUS AREAS AND FORESTRY DEVELOPMENT,TF023532-NTF-ESSD WB/WWF ALLLIANCE FOR FORESTRY

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment identifies
            erosion caused by the construction of feeder roads as the
            main anticipated negative impact. Other impacts include
            uncontrollable pasturage and soil erosion caused by
            livestock. Overuse of agrochemical inputs linked to
            agricultural intensification will be avoided by sensitizing
            and educating targeted populations through agricultural
            extension to disseminate information about integrated pest
            management. Ecosystem disturbance will be alleviated by
            avoiding the destruction of existing protective works. The
            exploitation of available water resources (the decrease of
            the water table and disturbance of the hydrological
            network), the increase in water use because of intensive
            agricultural production, uncoordinated maintenance of the
            forest or inappropriate cultural practices increasing
            erosion and siltation, accidental chemical spills-all could
            lead to flooding problems, a decrease in livestock
            resources, water pollution, and an amplification of
            socio-economic problems and would be exacerbated during the
            rainy season. These problems will be mitigated by
            integrating environmental protection into proposed methods
            for forest management, reforestation and revegetation, and
            selecting resistant plant species. Drainage works will
            control the flow of surface water. Providing filters and
            planting vegetation along embankments and among alluvial
            deposits and upstream water bodies will protect natural
            resources threatened by soil erosion and excavation.
